thread.title: Trump plans orders to roll back Obama’s climate rules | McCain as Trump critic-in-chief - MarketWatch
thread.title_full: Trump plans orders to roll back Obama’s climate rules | McCain as Trump critic-in-chief - MarketWatch

author: Robert Schroeder
title: Trump plans orders to roll back Obama’s climate rules | McCain as Trump critic-in-chief - MarketWatch
text:
President Donald Trump is preparing two more executive orders, this time aimed at curtailing Obama-era policies on climate and water pollution.
The Washington Post reports the orders could come as soon as this week . One will instruct the Environmental Protection Agency to start rewriting the 2015 regulation that limits greenhouse gas emissions from existing electric utilities. It also instructs the Interior Department’s Bureau of Land Management to lift a moratorium on federal coal leasing, the Post says. A second order will instruct the EPA and Army Corps of Engineers to revamp a 2015 rule that applies to 60% of the water bodies in the country.
Also read: Where Trump’s early flurry of executive orders ranks .
McCain as Trump “critic in chief”: President Trump said at his recent news conference that his administration is operating like a “fine-tuned machine.” Sen. John McCain, an Arizona Republican, believes otherwise. “In many respects, this administration is in disarray, and they’ve got a lot of work to do,” says McCain in a New York Times article about his criticism of the Trump White House. The Times writes that for a senator who supports free trade, backs NATO, remains suspicious of Russian intentions and has favored an assertive foreign policy, the differences with Trump have been profound.
Border tax players: The Hill has a list of seven players in the debate over House Republicans’ border tax proposal , including a key proponent — House Speaker Paul Ryan — and a leading critic, Sen. David Perdue, a Georgia Republican. The proposal is facing mounting opposition from business groups and many GOP lawmakers worried that consumers will be hit with higher prices for goods. Supporters say it would boost U.S. manufacturing.
Budget hit list: Also in the New York Times, the White House budget office has drafted a hit list of programs that Trump could eliminate to trim domestic spending, including longstanding conservative targets like the Corporation for Public Broadcasting, the Legal Services Corporation, AmeriCorps and the National Endowment for the Arts and the Humanities.
